sp.p: By my faith, but you shal answere as I wood haue you then.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Alwaies put in with aduice of your secretarie, neece, come, what answere you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Since you needes will haue my Answere, Ile Answere 〈◊〉 to the first, and last part of his letter.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Doe so Neece, and leaue the midst for him|selfe a gods name, what is your answeare?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I cannot but suffer you to loue, if you do loue.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Why v●ry good, there it is, and will requit your loue; say you so?He writes and she dic●ates.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Beshrowe my lipps then my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Beshrowe my fingers but you shall; what, you may promise to requite his loue, and yet not promise him marriage I hope; wel, and will requite your loue.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord hold your hand, for ile bee sworne, ile not set my hand ●oo't.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: VVell hold of your hand good madam till it shood come on, Ile be readie for it anon, I warrant ye● now forth; my Loue is without passion, and therefore free from alteration, what answere you to that madam?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Euen this my Lorde, your Loue being mentall, needes no bodely Requitall.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: I am Content with that, and here it is; but in hart.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: VVhat but in hart?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Hold of your hand yet I say, I doe embrace and repaie it,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You may write vnckle, but if you get my hand to it,

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Alas Neece this is nothing, ist any thing to a bodely marriage, to say you loue a mā in Soule if your harts agree and your bodies meet not? simple marriarge rites, now let vs foorth: hee is in the way to felicitie, and desires your hand.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: My ha●d shall alwaies signe the way to felicitie.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Very good, may not any woman say this now. Conclud now sweet Neece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And so God prosper your Iourney.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p:
Charitably concluded, though farre short of that ●oue I wood haue showen to any friend of yours
Neece I sweare to you, your hand now, andlet this lit|tle stay his appetite.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Read what you haue writ my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: What needs that madam, you remember it I am sure.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well if it want sence in the Composition, let my secretarie be blam'd for't, theirs my hand.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Thanks gentle Neece, now ile reade it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: VVhy now, more then before I pray?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: That you shall see straite, I cannot but suffer you to loue if you doe loue and wil requite your loue.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Remember that requitall was of your own put|ning it, but it shal be after my fashion I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Interrupt me no more, your loue being men|toll needs no bodely requital●, but in hart I embrace & repay it; my hand shall alwaies signe the way to felicitie, and my selfe knit with you in the bandes of marriage e|uer walke with you, in it, and so God prosper our iour|ney:

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Gods me life, tis not thus I hope.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: By my life but it is Neece.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: By my life but tis none of my deed then.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Doe you vse to set your hand to that which is not your deed, your hand is at it Neece, and if there be any law in England, you shall performe it too:

lg.l: VVh, ythis is plaine dishonoured deceit.
Does all your truest kindnes end in lawe?
Haue patience Neece, for what so ere I say
Onely the lawes of faith, and thy free loue
Shall ioyne my friend and thee, or naught at al,
By my friends loue, and by this kisse it shall.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: VVhy, thus did false Accontius snare Cydippe.

lg.l: Indeed deere loue his wile was something like
And then tis no vnheard-of●recherie
That was enacted in a goddes Eye,
Acconti●s wort●ie loue feard not Diana
Before whome he contriu'de this sweete deceite

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: VVel there you haue my hand, but ile besworne I neuer did thing so against my will.

lg.l: T'will proue the better madam, doubt it not▪
And to allay the billows of your blood,
Rais'de with my motion bold and opposite
Deere neece suppe with me, and refresh your spirites:
I haue inuited your companions
VVith the two guests that dinde with you to daie,
And will send for the old Lord Furnifall
The Captaine, and his mates and (tho at night)
VVe will be merrie as the morning Larke.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No, no my Lord, you will haue Clarence there.

lg.l: A las poore gentleman I must tell you now
Hees extreame sicke, and was so when he writt
Tho he did charge me not to tell you so;
And for the world he cannot come abroade.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Is this the man that without passion loues

lg.l: I doe not tell you he is sicke with loue;
Or if he be tis wilfull passion.
VVhich he doth choose to suffer for your sake
And cood restraine his sufferance with a thought,
Vppon my life he will not trouble you;
And therefore worthie neece faile not to come.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I will on that condition.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Tis perform'd: for were my friend well and cood comfort me; I wood not now intreate your com|panie, but one of you I must haue, or I die, oh such a friend is worth a monarchie.

div.stage: Enter Lord Furnifall. Rudsbie. Goose|capp●. Fowlweather. Bullaker.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay my gallants I will tell you more.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Forth good my Lord.

lg.l: The euening came and then our waxen stars
Spa●kled about the heauenly court of Fraunce.
VVhen I then young and readiant as the sunne
G●ue luster to those lampes, and curling thus
My golden foretoppe▪ stept into the presence,
Where set with other princely dames I found
The Countesse of Lancalier and her neece
VVho as I told you cast so fix'd an eye
On my behauiours talking w●th the king:

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: True my good Lord.

lg.l: They rose when I came in, and all the lights
Burnd dim for shame, when I stood vp and shind.

sp.speaker: Fou●
sp.p: O most passionate description Sir Cutt:

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: True of a candles end.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: The passingst description of a candle, that euer liu'd Sir Cutt:

lg.l: Yet aymd I not at them, nor seemd to note
VVhat grace they did me, but found courtly cause
To talke with an accomplisht gentleman
New come from Italie, in quest of newes▪
I spake Italian with him.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What so young?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: O rarissime volte cad●no nel parlar nostro familiare.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Slidd a cood speake it knight, at three yeare old.

lg.l: Nay gentle Captaine doe not set me forth
I loue it not, in truth I loue it not.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Slight my Lo●d but truth is truth you know.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I dare ●nsure your Lordship, Truth is truth, & I haue heard in Fraunce, they speake French as well, as their mother tongue my Lord.

lg.l: VVhy tis their mother tonge my noble knight▪
But (as I tell you) I seem'd not to note
The Ladies notes of me, but held my talke,
with that Italionate Frenchman, and tooke time
(Still as our conference seru'd) to shew my Courtship
In the three quarter legge, and setled looke,
The quick kisse of the toppe of the forefinger
And other such exploytes of good Accost;
All which the Ladies tooke into their eyes
VVith such attention that their fauours swarm'de
About my bosome, in my hatt, mine eares,
In skarffes about my thighes, vpon mine armes
Thicke on my wrystes, and thicker on my hands,
And still the lesse I sought, the more I found.
All this I tell to this notorious end,
That you may vse your Courtship with lesse care
To your coy mistress●s; As when we strike
A goodly Sammon, with a little line
VVe doe not tugge to hale her vp by force
For then our line wood breake, and our hooke lost;
But let her carelesse play alongst the stre●me
As you had left her, and sheele drowne her ●elfe.

sp.speaker: Foul
sp.p: A my life a most ri●h comparison.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Neuer stirre, if it bee not a richer Caparison, then my Lorde my Cosine wore at tilt, for that was bro|dred with nothing but mooneshine ith the water, and this has Sāmons in't; by heauen a most edible Caparisō.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Odious thou woodst say, for Cōparisōs are odious.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: So they are indeede sir Cu●▪ al● but my▪ Lords.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Bee Caparisons odious Sir Cutt: what like flow|ers?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: O asse they be odorous.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: A botts athat stincking worde odorous, I can neuer hitt on't,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And how like you my Court-counsaile gallāts ha▪

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Out of all proportion excellent my Lord: & be|lee●e it for Emphaticall Courtship, your Lordship puts downe all the Lords of the Court.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No good Captaine no.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: By Fraunce you doemy Lord for Emphaticall Courtship.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: For Emphaticall Courtship indeed I can doe somewhat.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Then does your merrie entertainment become you so festifally, that you haue all the brauerie of a Saint Georges day about ye when you vse it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay thats too much in sadnes Captaine.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p:
O good my Lord, let him prayse you, what so ere
it costs your Lordshippe.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: I assure your Lordshippe your merrie behaui|our does so festifally showe vpon you, that euery high holliday when Ladies wood bee most bewtifull; eue●y one wishes to God shee were turnd into such a little Lord as you, when y'are merrie.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: By this fire they doe my Lord, I haue heard am.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Marrie God forbid knight they shood be turnd into me; I had rather be turnd into them amine honor.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Then for your Lordships quippes, & quick iests, why Gesta Romanorum were nothing to them a my vertue

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well, well, well, I will heare thee no more, I will heare thee no more, good Captaine, Tha'st an excellent witt, and thou shalt haue Crownes amine honour, and now knights and Captain, the foole you told me off, do you al know him?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I know him best my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Doe you Sir Gyles, to him then good knight, & be here with him, and here, and here, and here againe; I meane paint him vnto vs Sir Gyles, paint him liuely, liue|ly now, mygood knightly boy.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Why my go●d L●rd? hee will nere be long from vs, because we are all mortall you know.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Verie true,

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: And as soone as euer wee goe to dinner, and supper togeather,

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Dinner and supper togeather, whens that troe?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: A will come you in amongst vs, with his Cloake buttond, loose vnder his chinne.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Buttond loose my Lord?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I me Lord buttond loose still, and both the flaps cast o●r before, both his shoulders afore him.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Both shouldiers afore him?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: From before him hee meanes; forth good Sir Gyl●s.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Like a potentate My Lord?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Much like a ●otentate indeed.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: For all the w●rld like a Potentate S. Cut: ye know.

sp.speaker: Rud,
sp.p: So Si●.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: All his beard nothing but hai●e.

sp.speaker: Cud.
sp.p: Or something else.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Or something else as you say.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Excellent good.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: His Mellons, or his Apricocks, Orrenges al|waies in an vncleane hand kerchiffe very cleanely I warrant you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: A good nea●e foole Sir Gyles of mine honour.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Then hi● fine words that hee sets them in, con|catic●ll, a fine Annisseede wenche foole vppon ticket and so forth.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Passing strange wordes belieue me,

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Knoth euery man at the table, though he neuer saw him before, by sight and then will he foole you so finely my Lorde, that hee will make your hart ake, till your eyes runne ouer.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: The best that euer I heard, gray mercy good knight for thy merrie description, Captaine, I giue thee twentie companies of commendations, neuer to bee casheird.

div.stage: Enter Iacke and Will on the other side.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Saue your Lordship,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: My prettie cast of Merlins, what prophecies with your little maistershippes?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Things that cannot come to passe my Lord, the worse our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Why whats the matter pages?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: ●ow now my Ladies foysting hounds.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: M. Iack▪ M. Iacke; how do ye M. William, frolick?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Not s● frolicke, as you left vs Sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: VVhy wags, what news bring you a Gods name.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Heauie newes indeed my Lord, pray pardone vs.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Heauie newes? not possible your little bodies cood bring am then, vnload those your heauie newes I beseech ye?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: VVhy my Lord the foole we tooke for your Lord: is thought too wise for you, and we dare not presēt him,

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Slydd pages, youle not cheates of our foole wil ye?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: VVhy sir Giles, hees too dogged and bitter for you in truth, we shall bring you a foole to make you laugh, and he shall make all the world laugh at vs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I indeed sir Giles, and he knowes you so wel too

sp.speaker: Giles
sp.p: Knowe me▪ slight he knowes me no more then the begge● knowes his dish.

sp.speaker: ●a.
sp.p: Faith he begs you to be content sir Giles, for he wil not come.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Begg me? slight I wood I had knowne that, to|ther daie, I thought I had met him in Paules, & he had byn anie body else but a piller, I wood haue runne him through by heauen, beg me?

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: H● begges you to be content sir Giles, that is, he praies you▪

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O does he praise me, then I commend him.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Let this vnsutable foole goe sir G●les, we will make shift without him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: That we wil a my word my Lord, and haue him too for all this.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Doe not you say so sir Giles, for to tel● you true that foole is dead.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Dead? Slight that cannot be man, I knowe he wood ha writ to me ont had byn so.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Quick or dead let him goe sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I my Lord, for we haue better newes for you to harken after.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: what are they my good Nou●tions?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: My Lord Momford intreates your Lorship and these knights and captaine to accompany the countesse Eugenia and the o●her two Ladies at his house at supper to night.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: All desiring your Lo: to pardon them, for not eating your meat to night.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: VVithall my hart wagges, and theirs amends; my harts, now set your courtshippe a'the last, a'the tain|ters, and pricke vp your sel●es for the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O braue s●r 〈◊〉 come 〈◊〉 prick vp the Ladies:

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: A●d wil not the knights two noble kinsemē be there?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Both will be their my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: VVhy theres the whole knot of vs then, and there shall wee kno●ke vppe the whole triplicitie of your nuptials.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: ●e make my Lord my Cosin speake for me.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: And your Lordship will be for me I hope.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: VVith tooth and naile Captaine, A my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rua.
sp.p: Hang am Tytts ile pommell my selfe into am.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Your L●: your Cosin S●r Gyles has promist the Ladies they shall see you sowe.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Gods mee, wood I might neuer be mortall if I doe not carty my worke with me.

lg.l: Doe so Sir Gyl●s, and withall vse meanes
To taint their high blouds with the shafte of Loue,
Sometimes a fingers motion woundes their minds;
A iest, a Iesture, or a prettie laugh.
A voyce, a present, ah, things done ith nick
VVound deepe, and sure, and let flie your gold
And we shall nuptialls haue hold belly hold.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O rare Sir Cutt: we shall eate nut-shells. hold belly hold

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: O pittifull knight, that koowes not nuptialls from nutshells.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And now Comme port● vous monsieur?

sp.speaker: Bull
sp.p: Porte bien vous remercy.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: VVe may see it indeed Sir, & you shall goe afore with vs.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: No good monsieurs.

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: Another Crashe in my Ladies Celler yfaith mon|sieur.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Remercy de bon ceur m●nsieurs.

lg.l: How now my friend does not the knowing beames
That through thy cōmon sence glaūce through thy eyes
To reade that letter, through thine eyes retire
And warme thy heart with a tryumphant fire?
My Lord I feele a treble happines
Mix in o●e soule, which proues how eminent
Things endlesse are aboue things temporall,
That are in bodies needefully confin'de;
I cannot suffer their dementions pierst
VVhere my immortall part admits expansure
Euen to the comprehension of two more
Commixt substantially with her meere selfe.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: As how my strange, and riddle▪ speaking friend?

lg.l: As thus my Lord, I feele my owne minds ioy
As it is separate from all other powers,
And then the mixture of an other soule
Ioyn'de in direction to one end, like it,
And thirdly the contentment I enioy,
As we are ioynd that I shall worke that good
In such a noble spirit as your neece,
VVhich in my selfe I feele for absolute;
Each good minde dowbles his owne free content
VVhen in an others vse they giue it vent.
Said like my friend, and that I may not wrong
Thy full perfections with an emptier grace,
Then that which showe presents to thy conceits,
In working thee a wi●e worse then she seemes;
●e tell thee plaine a secret which I knowe.
My neece doth vse to paint herselfe with white
VVhose cheekes are naturally mixt with redd
Either because she thinks pale-lookes moues most:
Or of an answereable nice affect
To other of her modest qualities;
Because she wood not with the outward blaze
Of tempting bewtie tangle wanton eies;
And so be troubled with their tromperies:
VVhich 〈◊〉 as thou wilt. I make it known●
That thy free comment may examine it,
As willinger to tell truth of my nee●e,
Then in the least degree to wrong my friend.
A ielous part of friendshippe you vnfold;
For was it euer seene that any dame
Wood chainge of choice a well mixt white and redd
For bloodles palenes, if she striu'd to moue?
Her painting then is to shunn motion,
But if she mended some defect with it
Breedes it more hate then other ornaments;
(Which to supplie bare nature) Ladies weare?
What an absurd thing is it to suppose;
(If Nature made vs either lame or sick,)
VVe wood not seeke for sound lymmes, or for health
By Art the Rector of confused Nature?
So in a face if Nature be made lamer
Then Art can make it, is it more offence
To helpe her want there then in other limmes?
Who can giue instance where dames faces lost
The priuiledge their other parts may boast.
But our most Court receiued Poets saies
That painting is pure chastities abator.
That was to make vp a poore rime to Nature.
And farre from any Iudgment it confered
For lightnes comes from harts, and not from lookes
And if inchastitie possesse the hart;
Not painting doth not race it, nor being cleare
Doth painting spot it,
For outward fairenes beares the diuine forme,
And moues beholders to the Act of loue;
And that which moues to loue is to be wisht
And eche thing simplie to be wisht is good.
So I conclude mere painting of the face
A lawfull and a commendable grace▪
VVhat paradox dost thou defend in this
And yet through thy cleare arguments I see
Thy speach is farr exempt from flatterie,
And how illiterate custome groslie erres?
Almost in all traditions she preferres.
Since then the doubt I put thee of my neece,
Checks not thy doubtlesse loue, forth my deare friend,
And to all force to those impressions,
That now haue caru'd her phantasie with loue,
I haue invited her to supper heere.
And told her thou art most extreameli● sick.
VVhich thou shalt counterfeit with all thy skill,

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: VVhich is exceeding smale to counterfeit,

lg.l: Practise a little, loue will teach it thee,
And then shall doctor Versey the phisitian,
Come to thee while her selfe is in my house.
VVith whome as thou confer'st of thy disease,
Ile bring my neece with all the Lords and Ladies.
VVithin your hearing vnder fain'd pretext,
To shew the pictures that hang ●eere thy chamber,
VVhere when thou hearst my voyce, know she is there.
And therefore speake that which may stir her thoughts,
And make her flie into thy opened armes.
Ladies whome true worth cannot moue to ruth
Trew louers must deceue to shew their truth

div.head: SCAeNA PRIMA.
div.stage: Enter Momford, Furnifall, T●es, Kingcob, Rudesbi●, Goosecap, Fou●weather, Eugenia, Hippolita, Penelope, Winnifred.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: VVhere is Sir Gyles Goosecappe here?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Come forward knight t'is you that the La|dies admire at working a mine honor.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: A little at once my Lorde for Idlenes sake.

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.p: Sir Cut, I say, to her captaine.

sp.speaker: P●nel:
sp.p: Come good ser●ant let's see what you worke.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: VVhy looke you mistris▪ I am makeing a fine drie sea, full of fishe, playing in the bottome, & here ile let in the water so liuely, that you shall heare it rore.

sp.speaker: Eug:
sp.p: Not heare it Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Yes in sooth madam with your eyes.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: I Ladie; for when a thing is done so exceede|ingly to the life, as my knight●e cosen does it, the eye oftentimes takes so strong a heede of it, that it cannot containe it alone, and therefore the eare seemes to take part with it.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: That's a verie good reason my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: VVhat a Iest it is, to heare how seriouslie he striues to make his foolish kinsmans answeres wise ones.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: VVhat shall this be seruant?

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: This shall be a great whale mistris, at all his bignesse spouting huge hils of salt-water afore him, like a little▪ water squirt, but you shall not neede to feare him mistris, for he shalbe si●ke and gould▪ he shall doe you noe harme, and he be nere so liuely.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Thanke you good seruant.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: Doe not thinke Ladie, but he had need tell you this a forehand for a mine honor, he wrought me the monster Caucasus so liuely, that at the first sight I started at it.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: The monster Caucasus my Lord? Cauca●s is a mountaine; Cacus you meane.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: Cacus indeede my Lorde, crie you mer|cie.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: Heere ile take out your eye, and you wil mistris.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: No by my faith Seruant t'is better in

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: VVhy Ladie, Ile but take it out in iest, in carnest.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: No, something else there, good seruant.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: VVhy then here shall be a Camell, and he shall haue hornes, and he shall looke (for al the world) like a maide without a husband.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O bitter sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Nay he has a drie wit Ladie I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: He bobd me there indeede my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Marry him sweet Lady, to answere his bitter bob.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: So she maie answere him with hornes indeed.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: See what a pretie worke he weares in his boote▪hose.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Did you worke them your selfe sir Gyles, or buy them?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I bought am for nothing madam in th'ex|ange

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Bought am for nothing.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Indeed madam in th'exchange they so honor him for his worke that they will take nothing for anie thing he buies on am; but wheres the rich night-cappe you wrohgt cosen▪ if it had not byn too little for you, it was the best peece of worke, that euer I sawe.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: VVhy my Lord, t'was bigg enough, when I wrought it, for I wore pantables then you knowe.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Indeede the warmer a man keepes his feete the lesse he necdes weare vppon his head.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You speake for your kinsman the best, that euer I heard my Lord.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: But I beleeue madam, my Lord my cosen has not told you all my good parts.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: I told him so I warrant you cosen.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: VVhat doe you thinke he left out Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p:
Marrie madam I can take tobacco now, and I haue bought glow-wormes to kindle it withall, better
then all the burning glasses ith world.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Glowe-wormes sir Giles will they make it burne?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O od madam I feed am with nothing but fire, a purpose, Ile besworne they eat me siue faggots a|weeke in charcoale.

sp.speaker: Tal:
sp.p: Nay he ha● the strangest deuices Ladies that euer you heard I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.p: That's a strange deuice in deed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: But your sowing sir Gyles is a more gentlewo|man-like qualitie I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: O farr away, for now seruant, you nee de neuer marrie, you are both husband, and wife your selfe.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: Nay indeede mistris I wood faine marrie for all that, and ile tell you my reason, if you will.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Let's heare it good seruant.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: VVhy madam we haue a great match at foot-ball towards, married men against batchellers, & the married men be al my friends, so I wood faine mar|rie to take the married mens parts in truth.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: The best reason for marriage that euer I heard sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: I pray will you keepe my worke a little mistris; I must needes straine a little courtsie in truth.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: Gods my life I thought he was a little to blame.

sp.speaker: Rud:
sp.p: Come, come, you heare not me dame.

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.p: VVell said sir Cut, to her now we shall heare fresh courting.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: A las sir Cut, you are not worth the 〈◊〉, euery bodie saies you cannot loue, how soeuer you talke on't.

sp.speaker: Rud:
sp.p: Not loue dame? slydd what argument woodst haue of my loue tro? lett me looke as redde as scar|let a fore I see thee, and when thou comst in sight if the sunne of thy bewtie, doe not white me like a sheppards hollandl am a Iewe to my Creator.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O excellent.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Let mee burst like a Tode, if a frowne of thy browe has not turnd the verie heart in my bellie, and made mee readie to bee hangd by the heeles for a fort|night to bri●g it to the right againe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You shood haue hangd longer Sir Cut: tis not right yet,

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Zonnes, bid me cut off the best lymme of my bo|die for thy loue, and ile lai't in thy hand to proue it, doost thinke I am no Christian, haue I not a Soule to saue?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes tis to saue yet I warrant it, and wilbe while tis a soule if yo● vse this.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Excellent Courtship of all hands, only my Cap|taines Courtshippe, is not heard yet, good madam giue him fauour to court you with his voyce.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What shood he Court me with all else my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: VVhy, I hope madam there be other things to Court Ladies withall besides voyces.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I meane with an audible sweete song madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: VVith all my heart my Lorde, if I shall bee so much in debted to him.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Nay I will be indebted to your eares Ladie for hearing me sound musicke.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: VVell done Captaine, proue as it wil now.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: My Lord Doctor Versey the Physitian is come to see master Clarence.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Light and attend him to him presently.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: To master Clarence? what is your friend sicke?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Exceeding sicke.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: I am exceeding sorrie.

lg.l: Neuer was sorrow worthier bestowed
Then for the ill state of so good a man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Alas poore gentleman; good my Lord lets see him.

lg.l: Thankes gentle Ladie, but my friend is loth
To trouble Ladies since he cannot quitt them.
With any thing he hath that they respect.
Respect my Lord; I wood hold such a man
In more respect then any Emperor
For he cood make me Empresse of my selfe
And in mine owne rule comprehend the world.
How now young dame? what so dainly inspird
This speech hath siluer haires, and reuerence asks
And soner shall haue dutie done of me
Then any pompe in temperall Emperie.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Good madam get my Lord to let vs greet him.

lg.l: Alas we shall but wrong and trouble him.
His Contemplations greet him with most welcome.
I neuer knew a man of so sweet a temper
So soft and humble, of so high a Spirit.
Alas my noble Lord he is not rich,
Nor titles hath, nor in his tender cheekes
The standing lake of Impudence corrupts,
Hath nought in all the world, nor nought wood haue,
To grace him in the prostituted light.
But if a man wood consort with a Soule
VVhere all mans Sea of gall and bitternes
Is quite evaporate with 〈◊〉 holy flames,
And in whose powers a Doue-like Innocence
Fosters her owne deserts, and life and death,
Runnes hand in hand before them: All the Skies
Cleere and transparent to her piercing eyes,
Then wood my friend be something, but till then
A Cipher, nothing, or the worst of men.

sp.speaker: Foul.
sp.p: Sweet Lord lets goe visit him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pray good my Lord, whats that you talke on?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Are you come from your necessarie busines Sir Gyles? we talke of the visiting of my sicke friend Clarence.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O good my Lord lets visit him, cause I knowe his brother.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Know his brother, nay then Co●nt doe
not deni● him.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pray my Lord whether was eldest, he or his elder brother?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: O! the younger brother eldest, while you liue Sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I say so still my Lord, but I am so borne down with truth as neuer any knightith world was I thinke.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: A man wood thinke he speakes simplie now; but indeed it is in the will of the parents, to make which child they will youngest, or eldest: For often we see the younger 〈◊〉, wherein he is eldest.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Your Logicall wit my Lorde is able to make a|ny thing good.

lg.l: VVell come sweet Lords, & Ladies, let vs spend
The time till supper-time with some such sights
As my poo●e house is furnished withall
Pictures and Iewels; of which implements
It may be I haue ●ome wil please you much.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Sweet Lord lets see them.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: I thinke your disease Sir, be rather of the mind then the bodie.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Be there diseases of the mind Doctor?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: No question Sir, euen as there be of the bodie.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And cures for them too?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: And cures for them too, but not by Phisick.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You will haue their deseases, greifes? wil ye not?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Yes, oftentimes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And doe not greifes euer rise out of passions?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Euermore.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And doe not passions proceed from corporall distempers?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Not the passions of the mind, for the mind ma|ny times is sicke, when the bodie is healthfull.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But is not the mindes-sicknes of power to make the bodie sicke?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: In time, certaine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And the bodies ill affections able to infect the mind?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then if there bee such a naturall commerce of Powers betwixt them, that the ill estate of the one of|fends the other, why shood not the medicines for one cure the other?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Yet it will not you see. Heimihi quod nullus a●or est medicabilis herbis.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay then Doctor, since you cannot make any reasonable Connexion of these two contrarieties the minde and the bodie, making both subiect to passion, wherein you confound the substances of both, I must tell you there is no disease of the mind but one, and ●hat is Ignorance.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: VVhy what is loue? is not that a disease of the mind?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nothing so for it springs naturally out of the bloode, nor are wee subiect to any disease, or sorrowe, whose causes or effects simply and natiuely concerne the bodie, that the mind by any meanes partaketh, nor are there any passions in the Soule, for where there are no affections, there are no passions: And Affectus your master Gallen refers part●irascents, For illic est anima senti|ens vbi sunt affectus: Therefore the Rationall Soule can|not be there also.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: But you know we vse to say, my mind giues mee this or that, euen in those addictions that concerne the bodie.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: VVe vse to say so indeed, and from that vse comes the abuse of all knowledge, and her practize, for when the obiect in question onely concerns the state of the bodie? why shood the soule bee sorry or glad for it? if she willingly mixe her selfe, then shee is a foole, if of necessitie and against her will, A slaue, And so, far from that wisdome, and freedome that the Empresse of Reason, and an eternall Substance shood comprehend.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Diuinely spoken Sir, but verie Paradoxicallie.

div.stage: Ent●r Momford, Tales, Kingcob, Furnif; Rudes. Goos: Foul: Eugenia, Penelope, Hipposita, Winnifrid.

lg.l: Who's there?
I, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Bring hether the key of the gallerie, me thought I heard the Doctor and my friend.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I did so sure.

lg.l: Peace then a while my Lord
We will be bold to evesdroppe; For I know
My friend is as respectiue in his chamber
And by himselfe, of any thing he does
As in a Criticke Synods curious eyes
Following therein Pyth●goras golden rule.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Knowe you the Countesse Eugonia Sir?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Exceeding wel Sir, she's a good learned scholler.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then I perceiue you know her well indeed.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Me thinks you two shood vse much conference.

lg.l: Alas sir, we doe verie seldome meet,
For her esta●e, and mine are so vnequall,
And then her knowledge passeth mine so farre
That I hold much to sacred a respect,
Of hir high vertues to let mine attend them.
Pardon me Sir, this humblenes cannot flowe
Out of your udgment but from passion.
Indeed I doe accoun● that passion,
The verie high perfection of my mind,
That is excited by her excellence,
And therefore willingly, and gladly feele it.
For what was spoken of the most chast Queene
Of riche Pasiaca may be said of her.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: A most excellent Dictick.

lg.l: Come Lords away, lets not presume too much
Of a good nature, not for all I haue
VVood I haue him take knowledge of the wrong
I ru●ely off●r him: come then ile shewe
A few ●are Iewels to your honour'd eyes,
And then pre●t you with a common supper.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: ●wells my Lord, why is not this candlestick● one of yo●r iew● pray?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Yes marrre is it Sir Gyles if you will.

sp.speaker: Goos:
sp.p: ●is a most si●e candlesticke in truth, it wants nothing but the languages.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: The languages seruant, why the languages?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: VVhy mistris; there was a la●tin cand●estick h●re afore, and that had the languages I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.p: I thought he had a reason for it Ladie.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I and a reason of the Sunne too my Lord, for his father wood haue bin ashamed on't.

lg.l: VVell master Clarence I perc●iue your mind
Hath so incorparate it selfe wi●h flesh
And therein ratified that flesh to spirit,
That you haue need of no Phisitians helpe.
But good Sir euen for holy vertues health
And grace of perfect knowledge, doe not make
Those ground-workes of eternitie, you lay
Meanes to your ruine, and short being here:
For the too strict and rationall Course you hold
VVill eate your bodie vp; and then the world,
Or that small point of it, where virtue liues
VVill suffer Diminution: It is now
Brought almost to a simple vnitie,
VVhich is, (as you well know) Simplicior puncto.
And if that point faile once, why, then alas
The vnitie must onely be suppos'd,
Let it not faile then, most men else haue sold it;
Tho you neglect your selfe, vphould it,
So with my reuerend loue I leaue you Sir.
Thanks worthie Doctour, I do amply quite you
I proppe poore vertue, that am propt my selfe,
And onely by one friend in all the world,
For vertues onely sake I vse this wile,
VVhich otherwise I wood despise and scorne,
The world should s●ke and all the pompe she hugs
Close in her hart, in her ambitious gripe
Ere I sustaine it, if this slendrest ioynt
Mou'd with the worth that worldlings loue so well
Had power to saue it from the throate of hell

div.stage: He drawes the Curtaines and sits within them.

lg.l: Come on faire Ladies I must make you both
Familiar witnesses of the most strange part
And full of impudence that ere I plaide.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: VVhats that good madam?

lg.l: I that haue bene so more then maiden-nice
To my deare Lord and vnkle not to yeeld
By his importunate suite to his friends loue
In looke, or almost thought; will of my selfe
Farre past his expectation or his hope
In action, and in person greete his friend,
And comfort the poore gentlemans sick state.

sp.speaker: `Pen.
sp.p: Is this a part of so much Impudence?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No but I feare me it will stretch to more

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Mary madam the more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Marrie Madam? what shood I marrie him?

lg.l: You take the word me thinkes as tho you would,
And if there be a thought of such kind heate
In your cold bosome, wood to God my breath
Might blowe it to the flame of your kind hart.
Gods pretious Ladie, knowe ye what you say,
Respect you what I am, and what he is,
VVhat the whole world wood say, & what great Lords
I haue refused and might as yet embrace,
And speake you like a friend, to wish me him?
Madam I cast all this, and know your choyse
Can cast it quite out of the christall dores
Of your Iudiciall eyes: I am but young
And be it said without all pride I take,
To be a maid, I am one, and indeed
Yet in my mothers wombe to all the wiles
Weend in the loomes of greatnes, and of state:
And yet euen by that little I haue learn'd
Out of continuall conference with you,
I haue cride haruest home of thus much iudgment
In my greene sowing time, that I cood place
The constant sweetnes of good Clarence mind,
Fild with his inward wealth and noblenes;
(Looke madam here,) when others outward trashe
Shood be contented to come vnder here.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: And so say I vppon my maiden head.

lg.l: Tis well said Ladies, thus we differ then,
I to the truth-wise, you to worldly men:
And now sweet dames obserue an excellent iest
(At least in my poore iesting.) Th' Etl my vnckle
Will misse me straite, and I know his close drift
Is to make me, and his friend Clarence meete
By some deuice or other he hath plotted.
Now when he seekes vs round about his house
And cannot find vs, for we may be sure
He will not seeke me in his sicke ●iends chamber,
(I haue at al times made his loue so strange,)
He straight will thinke, I went away displeas'd,
Or hartelie careles of his hartiest sute.
And then I know there is no greife on earth
Will touch his hart so much, which I will suffer
To quite his late good pleasure wrought on me,
For ile be sworne in motion and progresse
Of his friends suite, I neuer in my life
VVrastled so much with passion or was mou'd
To take his firme loue in such ●elouse part.
This is most excellent madam, and will proue
A neecelike, and a noble frends Reuenge.
Bould in a good cau●e, then lets greet his friend,
VVhere is this sickly gentleman at his booke?
Now in good troth I wood theis bookes were burnd
That rapp men from their ●app before their time,
How does my vnckles friend, no other name
I need giue him, to whome I giue my selfe,
O madam let me rise that I may kneele,
And pay some dutie to your soueraigne grace.
Good Clarence doe not wo●ke your selfe disease
My Ladie comes to ease and comfort you.

sp.speaker: P●n:
sp.p: And we are handmaides to her to that end.

lg.l: Ladies my hart will breake, if it be held
VVithin the verge of this presumtuous chaire.
VVhy, Clarence is your iudgement bent to show
A common louers passion? let the world,
That liue● without a hart, and is but showe,
stand on her emtie, and impoisoned forme,
I knowe thy kindenesse, and haue seene thy hart,
Clest in my vnckles free, and friendly lippes
And I am onely now to speake and act,
The rit'es due to thy loue: oh I cood weepe▪
A bitter showe of teares for thy sick state,
I cood giue passion all her blackest rites.
And make a thousand vowes to thy deserts,
But these are common, knowledge is the bond,
The seale and crowne of our vnited mindes▪
And that is ra●e, and constant, and for that,
To my late written hand I giue thee this,
See heauen, the soule thou gau'st is in this hand.
This is the knot of our eternitie,
VVhich fortune, death, nor hell, shal euer loose.

sp.speaker: Ia:
sp.p: VVhat an vnmannerly trick is this of thy coun|tesse, to giue the noble count her vnckle the slippe thus?

sp.speaker: Wil
sp.p: Vnmannerlie, you villayne? O that I were worthie to weare a ●agger to an●e purpose for thy sake?

sp.speaker: Bul:
sp.p: VVhy young gentlemen, vtter your anger with your fists.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: That cannot be man, for all fists are shut you know, and vtter nothing, and besides I doe not thinke my quarrell iust for my Ladies 〈◊〉 in this cause, for I protest she does most 〈◊〉 miscarrie her selfe.

sp.speaker: Ia:
sp.p: Protest you sawsie Iack you, I shood doe my countrie and court-shippe good seruice to beate thy co●lts teeth out of thy head, for suffering such a reue|rend worde to passe their guarde; why, the oldest courtier in the world man, can doe noe more then protest,

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Indeede page if you were in Fraunce, you wood bee broken vpon a wheele for it, there is not the b●st Dukes sonne in Fraunce dares saie I protest, till h●e bee one and thirtie yeere old at least, for the inheritance of that worde is not to bee possest before.

sp.speaker: Wil,
sp.p: VVell, I am sorie for my presumtion then, but more sorie for my Ladies, marie most sorie ●or thee good Lorde Momforde, that will make 〈◊〉 most of a●l ●orie for our selues, if wee doe not fynde her out.

sp.speaker: la:
sp.p: VVhy alas what shood wee doe? all the starres of out heauen see, wee seeke her as fast as w●e can, if shee bee crept into a rush wee will seeke her out or burne her.

lg.l: Villaines where are your Ladies, seeke them
Out; hence, home ye monsters, nad stil keep you thereExeuut▪ Page●.
VVhere le●itie keepes, in her in constant Spheare,
A wa●e you pr●ious villaines, what a plague,
Of varried tortures is a womans hart?
How like a peacockes taile with different lightes,
They differ from them selues; the very ayre
Alters the aspen humors of their bloods.
Now excellent good, now superexcellent badd.
Some excellent good, some? but one of all:
VVood anie ignorant babie serue her friend,
Such an vnciuill part? Sblood what is learning?
An artificiall cobwebbe to catch flies,
And nourish Spiders, cood she cut my throate,
VV with her departure I had byn her calfe,
And made a dish at supper for my guests
Of her kinde charge, I am beholding to her,
Puffe, is there not a feather in this ●yre
A man may challenge for her? what? a feather?
So easie to be seene; so apt to trace;
In the weake flight of her vnconstant wings?
A mote man at the most, that with the sunne,
Is onely seene, yet with his radiant eye,
we cannot single so from other motes,
To say this mote is shee, passion of death,
She wrongs me past a death, come▪ come my friend,
Is mine, she not her owne, and theres an end.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Come vnckle shall we goe to supper now?

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Zounes to supper? what a do●r is this?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: A las what ailes my vnckle, Ladies see.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is not your Lordshippe well?

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Good speake my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: A sweete plague on you all, ye wittie rogues haue you no pittie in your villanous iests, but runne a man quite from his fifteene witts?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: VVill not your Lord-shippe see your friend, and neece?

lg.l: VVood I might sinke if I shame not to see her
Tush t'was a passion of pure Ielosie,
Ile now make her now a mends with Adoration.
Goddes of learning and of constancie,
Of friendshippe and euerie other vertue.
Come, come, you haue abus'de me now I know
And now you plaister me with flatteries.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: My Lord the con●ract is knit fast betwixt them

lg.l: Now all heauens quire of Angels sing Amen,
And blesse the●s true borne 〈◊〉 with their blisse,
And Neece tho you haue 〈◊〉 me in this,
Ile vnckle you yet in an other thing,
And quite deceiue your expectation.
For where you think you haue contracted harts
VVith a poore gentleman, he is sole heire
To all my ●arledome, which to you and yours
I freely, and for euer here bequeath;
Call forth the Lords, sweet Ladies let them see
This sodaine and most welcome Noueltie;
But ●rie you mercy Neece, perhaps your modestie
VVill not haue them pertake this sodaine matche.
O vnckle thinke you so, I hope I made
My choyce with too much Iudgment to take shame
Of any forme I shall performe it with.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: Said like my Neece, and worthy of my friend.

div.stage: Enter Furnifal, Tal: King: Goos: Rud: Foul: Ia: Will, Bullaker.

lg.l: My Lords, take witnes of an absolute wonder,
A marriage made for vertue, onely vertue,
My friend, and my deere neece are man and wife.
A wonder of mine honour, and withall
A worthie presedent for al the world;
Heauen blesse you for it Ladie, and your choyce.

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.p: Thankes my good Lord.

lg.l: An Accident that will make pollicie blushe,
And all the Complements of wealth and state,
In the succesfull and vnnumbred Race
That shall flowe from it, fild with fame and grace.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: So may it speed deere Countsse, worthy Clarence.

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.p: Thankes good Sir Cu●berd.

lg.l: Captaine be not dismaid, Ile marrie thee,
For while we liue, thou shalt ●y consort be.
By Fraunce my Lord, I am not grieu'd a whit,
Since Clarence hath her; he hath bin in Fraunce,
And therefore merits her if she were better.
Thē knights ile knit your happie nuptial knots,
I know the Ladies minds better then you;
Tho my rare Neece hath chose for vertue onlie,
Yet some more wise then some, they choose for both
Vertue, and wealth.
Nay 〈◊〉 then I plead
This goes with my choyce, Some more wise then some,
For onely vertues choise is truest wisedome.
Take wealth, & vertue both amongst you then,
They loue ye knights exreamely, and Sir 〈◊〉:
I giue the ch a st Hippolita to you▪
Sir Gyles this Ladie;
Nay stay there my Lord,
I haue not yet prou'd all his knightly parts
I heare he is an excellent Poet too.
That I forgot sweet Ladie; good Sir Gyles▪
Haue you no sonnet of your penne about ye?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Yes, that I haue I hope my Lord my Cosen.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why, this is passing fit.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Ide be ●oth to goe without paper about me against my mistris, hold my worke againe, a man knows not what neede he shall haue perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: VVell remembred a mine honour Sir Gyles:

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pray read my Lorde, I made this sonnet of my mistris.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay reade thy selfe man.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: No intruth Sir Cut: I cannot reade mine owne hande.

sp.speaker: Mom.
sp.p: VVell I will reade it.

lg.l: Three things there be which thou shouldst only craue,
Thou Pomroy, or thou apple of mine eye;
Three things there be, which thou shouldst longe to haue,
And for which three, each modest dame wood 〈◊〉,
Three things there be, that shood thine anger swage,
An English mastife, and a fine french page.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Sblood 〈◊〉, theres but two things, thou 〈◊〉 thy selfe.
VVhy Sir Cutt: thats 〈◊〉, the verse wood haue binne too long, and I had put in the third, S'light you are no Poet I perceiue.

sp.speaker: Pe●.
sp.p: Tis excellent seruant.

lg.l: Keepe it Ladie then,
And take the onely knight of mortall men.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Thanke you good my Lord as much as tho you had giuen me twentie shillings in truth, now I may take the married mens parts at footeball.

lg.l: All comforts crowne you all; & you Captaine
For merrie forme sake let the willowe crowne;
A wreath of willow bring vs hither straite.
Not for a world shood that haue bin forgot
Captaine it is the fashion, take this crowne.
VVith all my hart my Lord, and thanke ye too
I will thanke any man that giues me crownes.

sp.speaker: Mom.

lg.l: Now will we con●ecrate our readie supper
To honourd Hymen as his nuptiall rite,
In forme whereof first daunce faire Lords and Ladies
And after sing, so we will sing and daunce,
And to the skies our vertuous ioyes aduance.

sp.p: Now to the song, and doe this garland grace.

lg.head: Cant●.
lg.l: Willowe, willowe, willowe.▪
our captaine goes downe:
Willowe, willowe, willowe,
his vallor doth crowne.
The rest with Rosemarie we grac●,
O Hyme● let thy lights
With richest rayes guild 〈◊〉 face,
and feast harts with delights.
Willowe, willowe, willow,
we chaunt tothe skies:
And with blacke and yellows,
giue co●rtship the prize.
